turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: No, no Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I maybe wrong but I think it was Arkansas.

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And they answered it by saying, “We have inherent authority because we are the court and the legislature can do nothing about it.”

turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: Yes.
Well there was --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm happy to see that you do not follow that.

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: No, I'm not arguing here against the power of Congress at all.
As Your Honor knows, that -- that argument was conducted in the halls of the Senate at great length by Livingston and by others in the aftermath of Judge Peck.

There I take it that the contempt legislation of the 1830s establishes and led us to ask the question where the Congress was intruding upon the Judiciary's powers in narrowing the definition of contempt.
I take it also --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: None of them can take it away at the time.

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: I'm thinking --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are you sticking to the old idea of the original record -- that's an inherent power of the courts and the Congress is incapable of taking it away --

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: Actually, what makes me hesitate is the thought that it would be rather -- it would be crippling to the courts if no aspects of the contempt power remain because I think of many situations in which --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, on what basis would we say that no -- there is a limit to which Congress can go constitutionally, how would we say that?
What in the constitution would permit us to say --

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: I suppose the ultimate question is at what point would legislation, on this subject, go so far, be so crippling to the very function of the court that it could be an invasion of the principle of the separation of powers.
I don't know any other (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm thinking of an example that --

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: -- under which that I can really replace it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, where they deal with sentences as I recall it, am I right, that Congress has limited the sentence in a criminal contempt in certain situations (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: In certain situations --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr

turn.text: -- three years is the (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Suppose Congress could do what has done in narcotics field and say, for a conviction of criminal contempt in a given situation, there must be a mandatory sentence of five years or ten years?

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: Well, that question has never a risen because since 1789, the grant of authority to federal courts has been explicitly in terms of the discretion of the court.
The -- so far as the grant of authority is concerned, then there had been ceilings placed on the punishment which might be imposed in (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, your argument -- this intrudes on the concept of separation of powers.
It seems to me that really --

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: I'm not --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- so the ultimate result is all of these congressional intents of regulations.

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: No, I'm not -- I'm not attacking any congressional regulation in this case.

That was -- (Voice Overlap) in answer to Justice Black's question, whether there would ever be a point at which Congress would have to stop, whether the Congress could take away the whole scope of the contempt power and leave the courts nothing, even for the purpose, let us say of maintaining decorum in the courtroom, I don't know.
That's a troublesome question to me, I can't conceive the Congress ever would.
But I think the -- that is not a relevant interest to the constitutional issue we have here.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, it is relevant I think.
I suggest that it's relevant to the application of the jury trial, at least to me, very well.

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: Well, it's not relevant to the defense I'm offering for our position because we don't question the Congress to tell (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Mr. Spritzer, may I suggest the possible relevance as it tentatively appears to me, you are saying that contempt -- criminal contempt is something quite different from any other kind of offense against the law.

And the next proposition which is I think has been established in the colloquy that has occurred is that Congress has the power to regulate, prescribe up to some indefinite point with respect to contempt.
Now if that is so -- it seems to me there's quite a substantial burden of persuasion to -- on your part to establish that this is a different category and other crimes.

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: The Congress has the power to legislate upon many topics, which relate to the judiciary and those matters are essentially judicial.
The Congress could limit the avenue of appeal to this Court in certain categories of cases, that they're not --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Then you call that jurisdiction?
That's a matter relating to jurisdiction and similarly, perhaps we call anything a matter relating to crimes, criminal offenses.

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: I don't think one can gain much light on the question whether the framers regarded contempt is carrying the right of trial by jury, by posing the question whether the Congress can legislate in respect to the procedures in contempt cases.
I think, more light is obtained by going to such historical evidence as we have in (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: That's more -- more lights contained in the -- which you're coming to as I understand you --

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: Well my -- I'm trying to make a very (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- this other point about -- this being in a different category and it's troublesome.

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: Well, I think there are significant differences between violation of a court order and violation of a statutory command in the form of --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In that connection Mr. Spritzer, would it be -- could we get the opinion of the Attorney General in the case that the Chief Justice mentioned?

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: I'm sure we can.

turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- burial in Arlington.

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: I think -- I'm not familiar with the opinion though.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes --

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) provided for the court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- because it refers from this (Voice Overlap) what you're talking about it now?

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: Yes sir.
What I was about to say now is that in the case of violation of a court order as distinguished from violation of the statute, there has been a full judicial proceeding.
The precise duty of a particular defendant has been specifically defined in an adversary case in which he's been represented by a lawyer.
The issue has been refined.
The end product is the product of case by case adjudication or of an equity proceeding, a direction to the defendant to do or not to do something.

That particularization of the command following a full judicial proceeding I think makes that kind of an order significantly different and the consequences of the flouting of that kind of an order significantly different from a generalized legislative command addressed to the world at large.
The court's authority has been refined.
It has spoken in a particular case.
In this case, it heard repeated arguments.
It entered an order directing testimony.
It decided which question should be answered and which need not be answered.
It repeatedly directed their answer.

Now if that kind of a question -- if that kind of an order cannot then be implemented directly by the courts, it seems to me that the sanction of contempt will lose a great deal of it's promptness and it's sureness both of which.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You mean the sanction of criminal contempt.

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That certainly, the sanction of civil contempt, which maybe more appropriate for that very situation, would still be available.

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And in full strength?

turn.speaker: ralph_s_spritzer
turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer
turn.text: I think incidentally the availability of civil contempt, I think does emphasize the point I was making to Justice Fortas that there's a difference between a court order and a legislative command because you couldn't impose any sanction, civil or criminal contempt to implement a generalized, a legislative command.
The very reasons that you can impose a civil contempt sanction are that you have had this proceeding, this refinement of the case, this adjudication.

The reason the Southern District has been utilizing criminal contempt sanctions rather than civil contempt in this type of case I take it, is that it has concluded that the sanctions, the force of the sanction ought not depend in whether the refusal to testify occurs the last week that the grand jury is in session or the first week.

turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas

turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas

turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer

turn.text: A controversy between the judge and the counsel --

turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas

turn.label: Mr. Ralph S. Spritzer

My point rather is that the situations in which the contempt power is utilized and needed, frequently make it important and I think the case that follows next after this one gives some practical illustrations in another area.
Frequently, make it important in our view, that the Court have the power to proceed in its traditional fashion.
